bibl.title: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 15, 1890

div1.p: Lazear describes walks and sightseeing in Edinburgh.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, June 15, 1890
div1.p:
To-day I took a
very interesting walk with Norris
over the Pentland Hills. We started
at 10 o'clock this morning and got
back in time for dinner at 6

I was too tired on Sunday night to finish
my letter, and since then I have not
had time I received your two letters
on Monday with the enclosed letter from
Aunt Kate. I hope you did go to
Bedford. I have no doubt it would
do you good. I had hoped that your
stomach would be better when you got
proper food. You will have to go to
Bedford and get yourself toned up and
then we, will be careful next year
to go where we can have well cooked
food.

The walk I took on Sunday was
very pleasant, We walked clear
across the Pentland Hills most of
the way along a path. They are
great rugged mountains covered with
heathings

On Saturday afternoon I went
to the top of Nelson's Monument on
Calton Hill. There is a very
good view from the top. The city can
be well seen but otherwise the
view is simply a part of what can
be better seen from Arthur's Seat,
I went to the Exhibition on
Saturday night. The Edinburgh
people think a great deal of this
exhibition, and it really has some
very good exhibits but exhibitions
are always tiresome on the whole

Dr. Billing has been here
for the last few days. He called
at the Dissecting room to see
me but I was not there at the
time. He also sent his card
and I called yesterday not finding
him at home however. He was
is visiting one of the professors
at the University. They all think
a great deal of him. He leaves
this morning.

While on last Sunday's tramp we
took a little while out of our
course to see Lennox Castle.
There is nothing left but out corner
of the tower covered with ivy.
It was the residence of the Earl of Lennox
and was occupied for some time by
Mary Queen of Scots. I send an ivy
leaf from a vine growing on the walls.
I do not take much stock in gathering
mementos and such, and I will
not often bore you by sending dried
weeds.

Another Castle in this vicinity which
I will have to visit in Craigmillar.
This was also a residence of Mary
Stuart. After seeing these two I
shall think I shall have done
my duty in the matter of Ruins.

I suppose I ought to look at the
interior of Holyrood, but if it is no
better than the exterior. I shall not
waste much time on it.

A sight which I must see, is the
new Forth Bridge. It is said to
be a magnificent structure. I could
see one cantilever of it from
Arthur's Seat.
